column1: #JohnBrady	unknown-#JohnBrady-party	unknown-#JohnBrady-dob	unknown-#JohnBrady-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	270	Since the European Council last met
column2: another deadline in the Northern Assembly has come and gone
column3: with the DUP still refusing to re-enter the Executive. Ministers can no longer hold office and take decisions to support the people in the North. The DUP has cited concerns about the protocol
column4: but in reality it is holding democracy to ransom. There is no justification for putting Stormont on ice while talks about the protocol continue. While the DUP refuses to allow politicians in the North to do their jobs
column5: ordinary people pay the price as they are abandoned at the time of an unprecedented cost-of-living crisis. Ordinary workers and families are worried about paying their bills
column6: keeping the lights on and weathering the cost of the cost-of-living crisis. They cannot afford to be held to ransom by the DUP refusing to re-enter the Executive to work on protecting hard-pressed people from rising prices. Across the North
column7: people want to see their political leaders working together to tackle the big issues
column8: such as investing in the health system and ensuring people can pay their energy bills
column9: not political stunts and brinkmanship that grabs headlines but ultimately achieves nothing. The DUP must get back into the Executive without any more delay or posturing. It must accept the outcome of May’s election and get back to work. Issues around the protocol exist
column10: but they can be resolved through dialogue
column11: partnership and a genuine commitment to ensuring the needs of people in the North are met. This is a time for political leadership and a genuine commitment to delivering solutions
column12: not empty stunts and inflammatory rhetoric. I believe our European partners are determined to resolve the issues around the protocol. I hope the Taoiseach impressed on the leaders at the European Council the importance of stable governance in the North and the need for the British Government to stop placating the DUP’s antics and to genuinely deliver for the people in the North. It is crucial now that the British Government engages in good faith with constructive negotiations with the European Union and that it abandons the reckless approach of the past. The protocol protects all-Ireland trade
column13: the Good Friday Agreement
column14: communities and business in the North from the damage caused by Brexit. Indeed
column15: many businesses have spoken of the positive effects of the protocol
column16: as it gives them the best of both worlds through access to the British and EU markets. Many businesses have experienced how the protocol continues to help in the creation of jobs and attracting investment. While it is not perfect
column17: issues around the protocol can be resolved through good faith discussions. Indeed
column18: in the current economic climate
column19: the protocol must be built upon and protected rather than undermined. There is no credible alternative to the protocol
column20: and those who attack it while providing no alternative are absolutely fooling no one. It is to be hoped the Taoiseach made it clear to our European colleagues at the European Council that support for the protocol in Ireland is clear
column21: steadfast and crucial for protecting the North’s interests. I would also be interested to hear whether he made clear the need for the DUP to end its appalling boycott of the North’s democratic institutions and whether he secured support for the restoration of the political institutions in the North and the formation of an Executive that can make politics work for everyone in the North. I hope he secured commitments from European colleagues that they will continue to work on constructive solutions around the protocol and to insist the British Government and the DUP end their bad faith posturing and deliver solutions that genuinely meet the needs of the people in the North. I also welcome the Council’s ongoing support for the people of Ukraine amid their continuing struggle to bring an end to the brutal Russian invasion and partial occupation of their country. While reports of recent and ongoing Ukrainian military success
column22: particularly in Kherson
column23: lend themselves to the belief that the conflict is moving towards a scenario where we may well see a route emerging to a position where both sides may be able to engage in negotiations
column24: I believe this remains some way off at the moment. However
column25: every effort must be made to push for negotiations to bring the brutal invasion
column26: the occupation and war to an end. Undoubtedly
column27: there is growing pressure on Vladimir Putin as a result of the many military setbacks suffered by his forces since the Ukrainian counteroffensive began. Unfortunately
column28: the failure of EU leaders to come to an agreement to address the impacts of the global energy crisis on the Continent lays bare the soft underbelly of the western strategy of support of Ukraine. Ukraine’s military successes have made Russia more reliant on and likely to engage in the hybrid flank of war effort
column29: a major aspect of which is predicated on the Russian belief that the EU and the wider western world lacks the ability or will to sustain the ongoing economic
column30: social and political impact of its support for Ukraine. The ability of the Russian leader to instrumentalise energy and food supplies along with the fate of refugees and their impact on the EU
column31: not to mention the wider world
column32: remains a major concern. In particular
column33: the failure of the EU leaders to secure agreement at the European Council on the issue of price caps on energy supplies effectively undermines the Ukrainian war effort and offers succour to Putin in the longer term. On our own national situation
column36: we have witnessed in the Government’s failure to put in place a tangible and workable plan to accommodate the well-advertised number of refugees who were expected from Ukraine into Ireland is a disgrace. The Government and its supporters want to talk up the supposed benefits of undermining Irish neutrality in terms of the military role Ireland could play in the conflict in Ukraine
column37: yet it cannot accomplish its part in the key role asked of the EU by Ukraine
column38: which is preventing Russia from using those Ukrainian citizens forced to flee in the face of Russian aggression as an instrument to undermine the political will of the EU to continue the scale of its support for Ukraine. Now that Russia has sanctioned 52 Irish politicians
column39: will the Irish Government finally come to the realisation that we have to send a clear
column40: strong message to the Russians and Putin by terminating the Russian ambassador’s existence here in this State and finally make the decision to expel Yuri Filatov from Ireland? While the EU is firmly focused on the external threat of Russia to EU democracy
column41: it appears to be much less concerned at the ongoing threat to the values of democracy across the EU by the actions of individual member states in the use of spyware on EU citizens. That is according to the senior MEP charged with leading the inquiry into the use of Pegasus spyware. Sophie in ‘t Veld has accused the European Commission of ignoring the grave threat to democracy posed by the use of spyware by governments of EU member states and the failure of members to co-operate with her inquiry.The investigation has revealed that the phones of the French President
column43: and the President of the European Council
column46: opposition figures and journalists across Europe were being monitored. The Commission remains silent on the threat. According to Ms in 't Veld
column47: this has created a climate of lawlessness around the use of spyware on citizens within the EU. Is the Irish Government one of the EU governments that has refused to co-operate with the investigation into the use of Pegasus
column48: the hacking software sold by the Israeli surveillance company NSO Group

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	271	All European debate is still dominated by the ongoing invasion of Ukraine by the Russian Federation. It remains critical that Russia is called out at every international forum
column2: whether a meeting of the EU Council
column3: the Inter-Parliamentary Union
column4: which recently met in Kigali and brought together parliamentarians from every nation
column5: or the G20. Russia must be isolated as the sole aggressor responsible for the untold hardship being endured by the people of Ukraine and by the entire world in terms of food shortages
column6: fuel poverty and the massive inflation that is impacting citizens here and across the globe. The indiscriminate missile attacks on Ukraine's infrastructure
column7: designed to bludgeon the Ukrainian people into submission
column8: are quite unconscionable. They are pushing our Continent and the world closer to a full-scale war beyond the borders of Ukraine. What happened yesterday evening in Poland should send shock waves through all of us and every nation. A miscalculation
column9: mistake or malfunction can easily set in train unimaginable consequences. That is the position we are in. The liberation of parts of Donetsk have revealed many more potential Russian war crimes and crimes against humanity. This is unprecedented in Europe
column10: our Continent
column11: since the end of the Second World War. I also want to mention the sanctioning of 52 Irish politicians that was announced yesterday. Our Taoiseach
column12: most of the Cabinet
column13: many of us on these benches and our speaker
column14: our Ceann Comhairle
column15: are not welcome in Russia. They are banned from Russia. How can we have an ambassador down the road who tells the elected representatives of the Irish people they are not welcome? What is the response to that? We must have a robust and clear response because that is an assault on our democratic right to function as the voice and parliament of the people of Ireland. One of the clear impacts of Russian aggression has been and remains the energy crisis. Irish citizens
column16: like all others
column17: are struggling to ensure their homes are heated and energy bills can be afforded in the coming months as the temperature plummets. While I welcome the actions of the Government to date in seeking to mitigate the increased cost of fuel and everything else and to support struggling households and businesses
column18: more will have to be done. That is for another debate. It is important that a greatly accelerated plan of action on a pan-European level must be implemented to address security and affordability in the supply of energy and a speedy agreement on a windfall tax on those companies
column19: those large corporate entities
column20: who have seen huge profit increases on the basis of an international crisis. There are many issues demanding attention at European Council level. I give out on every occasion. These debates are intended to report back from European Council meetings and five-minute time limits for Members are ludicrously small. I will raise one issue of real importance. There are many other issues
column21: as I said
column22: demanding attention
column23: and humanitarian catastrophes can slip down the agenda and not receive the focus they deserve. I raise the issue of Somalia
column24: which today is experiencing yet another devastating humanitarian crisis. Millions of people are in danger of starvation and death. The Somali refugee crisis is one of the most significant mass displacements in the world. Drought in the Horn of Africa
column25: the impact of climate change
column26: has made a disastrous situation even worse. Its neighbouring countries
column27: Kenya and Ethiopia
column28: have endured an incredible change in climate that is causing food cost inflation that is disastrous. I ask the Minister of State to ensure these important issues are also kept in focus as millions of people struggle to exist.

column1: #SeanHaughey	unknown-#SeanHaughey-party	unknown-#SeanHaughey-dob	unknown-#SeanHaughey-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	272	As we know
column2: there has been political instability in Westminster for many weeks now. It has delayed negotiations between the UK and the EU on the implementation of the Northern Ireland protocol. As a result
column3: there has been no progress regarding efforts to put a functioning Executive in place in Stormont. Thankfully
column4: it seems the appointment of Rishi Sunak as British Prime Minister has brought this instability to an end
column5: a point put eloquently by Matt Hancock in the jungle on "I'm A Celebrity...Get Me Out Of Here!" A change of British Prime Minister on this occasion has indeed been a genuine chance to reset the relationship between Dublin and London. That certainly seems to be the case. The attendance of the British Prime Minister at the recent meeting of the British-Irish Council was significant and sent out all the right signals as regards future relationships on these islands. Thankfully
column6: the Northern Ireland Secretary of State
column7: Chris Heaton-Harris MP
column8: has listened to all parties and has extended the deadline for the calling of fresh elections to the Stormont Assembly. This effectively puts off a possible election until 13 April next at the latest. All sides now seem to be agreed that there should be a negotiated settlement to the protocol issue and that genuine concerns need to be addressed. The main issues now seem to be checks on goods moving from Britain to Northern Ireland and the role of the European Court of Justice. We must inject a new determination to resolve these problems
column9: to compromise where it is needed and to get these technical negotiations finalised as soon as possible. I also draw attention to the dire situation unfolding in the Horn of Africa and
column10: in particular
column11: Somalia
column12: Ethiopia
column13: Kenya
column14: Eritrea
column15: Sudan and South Sudan. Those countries are already prone to ongoing conflict. The region is now experiencing a five-season drought caused by climate change
column16: resulting in acute food insecurity and malnutrition
column17: and the associated spread of diseases such as pneumonia
column18: measles and cholera. The war in Ukraine is also taking its toll given that the global supply of grain and fertiliser has been curtailed
column19: which is especially impacting the Horn of Africa. Some 90% of wheat supplies in the Horn of Africa come from Russia and Ukraine. Global increases in the commodity prices of food and energy are making things even worse. In excess of 36 million people are experiencing severe drought in southern Ethiopia
column20: northern Kenya and Somalia. It is estimated this translates into severe food insecurity and malnutrition for more than 20 million people in the area. In southern Sudan
column21: in excess of 8 million people are experiencing serious food insecurity. The risk of famine is acute. Millions are fleeing these areas in search of food and water
column22: thus increasing ongoing conflicts even further. Many parts of the region experienced famine conditions in 2010 and 2011
column23: at which time the global community said this could not be allowed to happen again.It is happening again and it appears to many that the world is turning a blind eye to the unfolding catastrophe. How should Ireland and the global community respond to this humanitarian disaster? For a start
column24: Ireland must be to the forefront in highlighting this disaster both in the EU and at the UN
column25: including at the UN Security Council. We should emphasise in particular the role played by climate change. In addition
column26: humanitarian aid should be increased substantially by donor organisations in these countries. Our own overseas development aid
column27: ODA
column28: budget now totals €1.2 billion
column29: the highest on record and we must also continue to increase our funding package for this region both to Irish NGOs and to international aid organisations. Last month Dóchas
column30: Trócaire and Concern made a presentation to the Oireachtas Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on the situation in the Horn of Africa. Their reports from the region were shocking. These NGOs have since outlined a programme of action to tackle these problems
column31: action for the short term and action for the longer term. I hope the Government can respond positively to this proposed action plan. The European Council continues to express strong solidarity with Ukraine. This week
column32: Russia again bombarded several cities and power plants with missile strikes thus endangering the civilian population. Recent events in Kherson gave us all a little hope that Ukraine can successfully fight back. The retreat of Russian forces eastwards across the Dnipro river and the raising of the Ukrainian flag on government buildings in the previously annexed Kherson have given everybody a great morale boost. I hope that this setback will lead ordinary Russians to start to question the wisdom of the so-called special military exercise and Putin's regime generally. As winter arrives
column33: Europe must continue to stand resolutely with Ukraine. An eighth round of sanctions has been agreed and these need to be rigorously enforced. Further effective sanctions should be considered as the need arises. I understand the establishment of a military assistance mission for Ukraine was further considered by EU defence ministers this week. Ireland is committed to participating in this mission. Our expertise in de-mining and on improvised explosive devices has been talked about. The Minister should keep the House fully informed of developments in this regard. Ireland has supported Ukraine in other ways. We have given €20 million in humanitarian aid
column34: as well as a €66 million commitment for the European peace facility. We have also given a commitment of €3 million to the International Criminal Court
column35: which is establishing a case that war crimes have been committed by Russia in Ukraine. As we know
column36: last Friday the Supreme Court issued its judgment to the effect that the proposed method to ratify the Comprehensive Economic Trade Agreement
column38: between EU and Canada was unconstitutional. In short it ruled that CETA cannot be approved by the Dáil under Article 29.5.2° of the Constitution. The Joint Committee on European Union Affairs considered this agreement in detail. My view was that Ireland had nothing to fear from the investor court system. There seemed to be much scaremongering in this regard
column39: including exaggerated claims concerning the so-called "chill effect". I also believe it would not be practicable to renegotiate this agreement
column40: involving as it would the European Commission and Canada as well as all 27 EU member states in respect of their ratification procedures. Free trade is good for this country as a small open economy. The judgment indicates that a referendum on the agreement is not a legal requirement for ratification. In these circumstances I do not believe we should have one. It seems to me that a way forward is to change arbitration legislation in order that the High Court has powers to decline to give effect to decisions of the CETA tribunal where they are seen to compromise the constitutional identity of State or obligations to legislate for EU law.

column1: #MartinKenny	unknown-#MartinKenny-party	unknown-#MartinKenny-dob	unknown-#MartinKenny-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	273	Over recent weeks everybody has had growing concern about the situation in Ukraine. It took a very nasty turn over the last 24 hours with an enormous bombardment across Ukraine of missiles. One of the missiles
column2: whether it came from Russia or Ukraine
column3: landed in Poland. We should be very seriously concerned about the advancement of Russia's war. I am also concerned that Irish politicians have been placed on this list and we need to deal with that. The Government will have the support of everyone in the House to do something firm over what Russia intends to do regarding parliamentarians from these Houses who clearly stand with democracy and who clearly have a voice to be heard in respect of that. The big issue with the war in Ukraine and all these developments is security across Europe
column4: particularly food security and energy security. We need to have a co-ordinated effort across the European Union to deal with these issues. The previous speaker mentioned CETA. There is an element of international trade and elements which are blocking that and are causing issues in that regard. Of course
column5: many people have concerns about CETA and particularly the impact the investment court may have. We also need to deal with that. Developments in the past few days on both these issues concern us all and should concern the Government greatly. We need to ensure that we provide a solution to it. Clearly
column6: I think the solution that has been set out by the courts is that we need a referendum on CETA. That needs to happen as quickly as possible and Government needs to move to do that. The issues of food security and energy security in the European Union relate to an issue raised by another colleague here in regard to the Horn of Africa
column7: namely
column8: the impact that climate change is having on the entire world and our need to move away from fossil fuels including gas and to have alternatives. Each country in Europe cannot do that on its own; we have to work together to do that. We need co-ordinated efforts across the entire European Union not just to resolve the problems that we have with own addiction to fossil fuels
column9: but to resolve the problems the entire world has with global warming. Some changes have happened in the recent months internationally. The election in Brazil gives many people hope that there might be a change in respect of that. The lungs of the Earth
column10: the rainforests
column11: are somewhat safer than they were some time ago. Many people also took great hope from the elections in the US that things may be moving in the correct direction. Within the European Union we have had a number of elections recently. Italy and Hungary seem to be going in the opposite direction. We need to be firm over where the world politics needs to go. We need to look after people rather than vested interests. We need to look after the needs of our communities across the entire globe rather than looking after the needs of corporate interests. For too long that has been the play. It has been about the big corporations and what they need delivered for them rather than what needs to be delivered for the people. Overall
column12: the war in Europe and the situation with global warming are issues that need to be addressed in a co-ordinated fashion across the entire European Union.

column1: #GaryGannon	unknown-#GaryGannon-party	unknown-#GaryGannon-dob	unknown-#GaryGannon-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	274	I will begin where the previous Government speaker finished
column2: which was on the recent High Court ruling on CETA. Government Members have said that there is no legal requirement for a referendum. However

column4: perhaps there is a requirement for us to have that conversation and a referendum is certainly one way for us to do that. While there might not be a legal requirement
column5: there is certainly a civic requirement. In a country
column6: politicians have responsibility to convince the public. I would hold a very different view in believing there is an ethical and civic requirement for a referendum before we even attempt to ratify the parts of CETA including the investment courts. When the Deputy says that is nothing to worry about
column7: I note that some parts of Romania
column8: for example
column9: are currently being sued by a corporation.Even Scotland was sued by the alcohol industry over a decade ago. There is definitely a civic requirement for a referendum and we in the Social Democrats are pushing and supporting that call.  In terms of my discussion around the post-European Council statement
column10: I want to take a look at some of the Taoiseach’s comments. There is a confluence of crises happening that requires leadership and Ireland is in a unique position to provide strong moral leadership and to take a step out to the side. Hostilities are incredibly heightened at the minute and there is a responsibility on us and potentially on others to step outside the hostilities. While we condemn Russia's horrid invasion of Ukraine in the strongest terms
column11: we saw last night how quickly tensions can rise. I note for example that Germany's defence ministry last night was very quick to suggest sending aircraft to patrol Polish air space because the assumption that there were Russian rockets. Indeed
column12: they probably were Russian rockets but perhaps they came from Ukraine and went into Poland. We need to be extraordinarily careful. We need to step away from this jump to militarisation. There is a role for Ireland here. Our position as a country is that we have never invaded another and that
column13: along with our role on the UN Security Council
column14: means that we can be the people who step forward in the call for diplomatic solutions in the immediate term because the world is in a precarious place. Ireland must and will continue to support refugees and we must overcome the equity issues that arise in regards accommodation. It was announced yesterday for example in my own constituency of Dublin Central that it is likely that 600 Ukrainian refugees will be coming into Drumcondra and East Wall. In inner city Dublin and in Dublin Central as a whole
column15: we have played a massive part in welcoming and in being enhanced by the people who have come to us from Ukraine. We also need supports to help the people who came as refugees. That support must come in the form of childcare places and extra provision for education. Everybody is playing the part in our collective effort. I have not seen the level of hostility that has been talked about elsewhere
column16: but there are basic human needs for which we needs supports
column17: in the areas of education
column18: childcare places and in access to the jobs market. That can foster this continuing spirit of collective endeavour that we have seen. Energy bills have doubled in the EU capitals according to new data. The EU is in a deep crisis when it comes to energy this winter. That will further exacerbate the level of poverty that already existed in the European Union. I will make the point in all statements before and after every EU Council that poverty is the single greatest threat to the European Union. I believe at the moment one in five people in European Union are living in poverty. If people start to feel cold
column19: both in real and philosophical terms
column20: and if they do not feel the warmth of the EU
column21: that will be a real threat. We have seen that with Brexit
column22: where the communities that were left behind because of advancement were the same ones that went out and voted against being part of the European Union. If we are to have a place it needs to be to confront the everyday lived experiences of people within our borders.  I will briefly touch on COP27. The Minister for the Environment
column23: Climate and Communications
column24: Deputy Eamon Ryan
column25: said that loss and damage is the priority at COP27 and I endorse those that. It has to be. With that principle in mind
column26: we have to focus on the Horn of Africa. This issue has already been touched on by speakers such as Deputy Haughey and others. The drought
column27: famine and human tragedy that are unfolding in the Horn of Africa at present are unimaginable. We have to both play our part and stand forward and demonstrate as much leadership as possible because the tragedy that is happening there is unlike anything we have seen
column28: certainly in my lifetime. We need to support the charities that are working on the ground and that are getting whatever resources into those communities so that they can access water and food. We are seeing child loss of life on a scale that is simply tragic. Though so many other issues are currently happening
column29: I can think of no greater role that we can play than to be people who are standing up for those who are in need in the Horn of Africa and I hope that we can do that.  I wanted to touch on Italy’s recent elections and rule of order principles
column30: but I can talk about that next time.

#BrianLeddin	unknown-#BrianLeddin-party	unknown-#BrianLeddin-dob	unknown-#BrianLeddin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	276	I think Deputy Crowe is in a committee so I will keep going and if I use the eight minutes so be it. I commend Deputy Howlin on his strong speech with regard to the news today that Russia has essentially made 52 Members of the Oireachtas personae non grata. I do not know who these 52 are
column6: but it is outrageous that another state would treat a sovereign nation such as Ireland in this way. I want to add my voice to Deputy Howlin’s condemnation.  The Taoiseach in his statement mentioned COP27 and I raised it with in during Questions on Policy or Legislation yesterday. He showed leadership on the international stage in showing how we must deal with climate change. He said we do not have a minute to lose and I absolutely agree with him
column7: as I think Members across this House also do. The Government has shown leadership at home and the Oireachtas has generally shown leadership at home. I chair the Oireachtas Joint Committee on Environment and Climate Action and as best we can we have sought to achieve a consensus approach to what is necessary. This Oireachtas can be proud that we agreed quite overwhelmingly to bring in the Climate Action and Low Carbon Development (Amendment) Act 2021. Nobody said it was going to be easy and we have set ourselves an incredibly difficult target of reducing emissions by 51%
column8: based on a 2018 baseline
column9: by 2030. We are finding now as we move into the review of the climate action plan in the next few weeks just how hard it is. If you look at the numbers across every sector
column10: such as agriculture
column11: energy
column12: transport or any other sector
column13: the numbers do not lie
column14: and they make it difficult.  We are in a situation where we have set ourselves ambitious targets but are in danger of getting caught up in the rhetoric and perhaps patting ourselves on the back for setting such ambitious targets. What matters is achieving them. When the climate action plan comes out in a few weeks’ time
column15: it will show a refined path towards 2030
column16: but there will be a lot in there that will be quite difficult. All Members of this House have experience in their communities of where climate action is difficult because if you take a simple example of how we use our road space

column18: such as buses

column21: if that is the approach we take

column23: as well as the Upper House

column26: TEN-T

The Acting Chair knows haulage better than perhaps anyone in the House and I would be interested in chatting with her about this. Much of the haulage that is currently on our roads can be put on rail and carried more sustainably. Dublin Port is fairly choked with traffic. Just as there is for Rosslare

column1: #PatriciaRyan	unknown-#PatriciaRyan-party	unknown-#PatriciaRyan-dob	unknown-#PatriciaRyan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	277	I wish to speak briefly about Iran
column2: which was addressed at the recent European Council meeting. I send my solidarity to the ordinary citizens of Iran
column3: especially the women who are putting themselves at risk in challenging appalling human rights abuses. There needs to be a stronger response from the EU
column4: not just on this issue
column5: but on Iran's continuing support for Russia in the latter's brutal assault on Ukraine. The EU needs to go further to get the parties to that war around the table. There needs to be an agreed solution and that starts with a conversation. The EU must use its influence to make this happen. We saw last night how matters could escalate. Warmongering needs to stop. I implore the Minister of State to put equal effort into seeking peace. The ongoing war has affected energy security and energy prices. The recent meeting proposed several solutions
column6: which must be progressed immediately. We need a windfall tax on excess energy prices
column7: we need voluntary joint purchases of gas and we need to address the decoupling of gas and electricity markets. The market approach is not working. It is feathering the nests of multinational energy companies at the expense of ordinary workers and families
column8: in particular older people. Small businesses are dying on their feet and need a lifeline now.

column1: #MartinBrowne	unknown-#MartinBrowne-party	unknown-#MartinBrowne-dob	unknown-#MartinBrowne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	278	I welcome the recommitment of EU member states' solidarity with Ukraine as it continues to defend itself against annexation and I welcome the recent withdrawal of Russian forces from one of its regions. I wish to discuss the issues of energy and the economy

column3: in which reference is made to calling on the Commission to submit concrete decisions urgently on a temporary EU framework to cap the price of gas and electricity generation. I note that mention is made of doing this while preventing gas consumption increasing. I understand why this was mentioned and its importance
column4: but how long is it likely to take the Commission to make such a submission? Has the Commission contacted the Council regarding the progress made to date? I wish to ask about the progress being made by the Government in putting into action the regulation agreed at European level on a windfall tax. The need for urgency in this regard cannot be overemphasised
column5: but the Government seems to be taking its time in implementing the regulation. I must express my extreme dissatisfaction with the Minister's seemingly relaxed attitude to this
column6: all while households and businesses are struggling. What is the delay in implementing this regulation-----

#MartinBrowne	unknown-#MartinBrowne-party	unknown-#MartinBrowne-dob	unknown-#MartinBrowne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	280	-----and will the Minister of State outline when he foresees it finally happening? column3: it is our responsibility to drive the transformation necessaryIn Ireland

column7: instead of reducing

Words are fine but
column17: as the UN Secretary-General said
column18: politicians and big business are saying one thing but doing another. He said: "Simply put
column19: they are lying." The reason they are lying is because they are wedded to an ecocidal capitalist system that is based around the profits of the big fossil fuel corporations globally and
column20: in this country
column21: the profits of big agribusiness. That is why we have to overthrow this system and we need eco-socialist change. I wish to raise a point about loss and damage. Last year

column3: and we must remember this.

There is no set time for questions. We have a 20-minute slot and five Members are present
column2: along with the Minister of State. I assume everyone wants to ask a question. Will we work with a minute and a half per question and a minute and a half per response
column3: or do Members want two minutes per question and two per response?

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	296	Two minutes.

#VeronaMurphy	unknown-#VeronaMurphy-party	unknown-#VeronaMurphy-dob	unknown-#VeronaMurphy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	297	Agreed. We will start with Deputy Brady.

#JohnBrady	unknown-#JohnBrady-party	unknown-#JohnBrady-dob	unknown-#JohnBrady-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	298	I want to follow up on the point several Deputies and I made on the Russian decision to sanction 52 Members of this House of the Oireachtas. It is very clearly an attempt to silence critics who have rightly decided to stand with Ukraine against the brutal occupation and invasion seven months ago. I reiterate my call
column2: a call made by Members of this House and others over the past seven months
column3: to move finally to expel the propagandist in situ in this city
column4: Mr. Yuriy Filatov
column5: who represents the brutal occupying force of Russia. The attack on the democratic Houses here and democracy itself by sanctioning 52 Members has to be met with a very strong message from the Government. What actions will the Government finally take? Will it finally take the decision to expel the mouthpiece for the brutal invasion force of Russia
column6: Putin's spokesman in Ireland? Will the Irish Government finally move to expel Mr. Filatov?

column1: #ThomasByrne	unknown-#ThomasByrne-party	unknown-#ThomasByrne-dob	unknown-#ThomasByrne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	299	In numerous instances
column2: we have seen Russia try deliberately to provoke division or discord in democratic nations. I am absolutely convinced that Russia
column3: in this particular manoeuvre
column4: whatever it is
column5: will try to do the same. It will try to divide us. It tried to do it with the fishers and tried to do it many other times over recent years. There were certainly people supporting it in that endeavour over recent years. All we know is what is in the media reports and what the Russian Foreign Ministry has published on its website. We know no more than that. We do not have a list of names. Some Ministers in the Government were listed on a press release but many others were not. We are certainly not going to overreact to this. I have no idea what the sanctions entail but am quite certain that nobody on the list
column6: certainly those in the political world
column7: has any assets in Russia
column8: any bank accounts there or any reason to visit it any time soon. We would all love to visit Russia if it were to become a democratic state and if it were brought back into the normal democratic system of the world. That is not likely anytime soon. Therefore
column9: we are not going to react to something on which
column10: as yet
column11: we have no information. We certainly believe we have taken a united approach to the Russian Federation and the brutal assault on Ukraine. All our democratic focus in this House should be on Russia
column12: which is 100% responsible for what has happened. If there is anything to react to
column13: I have no doubt the Government will make decisions
column14: but at the moment it simply does not have the information to hand. I suspect we will have very little to do as a result of this decision by the Russian Federation.

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	300	I have two questions. First
column2: I want to revisit the question just posed. I find the Minister of State's response entirely unacceptable. I refer to the notion of not overreacting. There has never
column3: from my recollection
column4: been a situation where the Ceann Comhairle of Dáil Éireann was sanctioned and told he was not allowed to visit a country with which we have diplomatic relations. Where 50 Members of the Houses of the Oireachtas
column5: including members of the Government
column6: including the Taoiseach and Tánaiste
column7: are told without precedent that they are personae non gratae in a country with which we have diplomatic relations
column8: it is hardly an overreaction to do something stronger than simply say Putin is trying to divide us. Putin is a bully and
column9: like all bullies
column10: needs to be stood up to. I ask the Minister of State to reflect again on what action the Government will take if what has been described proves to be the case. My second question is on the issue of the Horn of Africa. I am deeply concerned that because of the focus on Ukraine
column11: an increasing number of countries are retrenching their bilateral supports to developing countries in general
column12: but those in Africa in particular. This happened in a now-non-EU country
column13: the UK
column14: when its Department for International Development was subsumed under the department responsible for foreign affairs. I understand it is now happening in Sweden. There is much more focus on migration in Europe and Ukraine
column15: and areas like the Horn of Africa are being taken out of focus. In his discussions with his EU colleagues in particular
column16: will the Minister of State ensure there is a focus on catastrophic events in the Horn of Africa?

column1: #ThomasByrne	unknown-#ThomasByrne-party	unknown-#ThomasByrne-dob	unknown-#ThomasByrne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	301	On the announcement from the Russian Federation
column2: we have no information other than a very brief statement
column3: which does not even name the people it states it is sanctioning.

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	302	Would the Minister of State not call in the Russian ambassador and ask whether there is truth in it?

#ThomasByrne	unknown-#ThomasByrne-party	unknown-#ThomasByrne-dob	unknown-#ThomasByrne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	303	This has come to light while we have been sitting. There may well be actions taking place in the Department of Foreign Affairs at the moment. I believe this became public sometime after 1 o'clock today
column2: so it is breaking news. The idea that I would come in here with a formulated response to something that has appeared on a website in the past couple of hours would not be correct. Our entire focus is on helping Ukraine. We can stand here and say how terrible this statement is but all the while missiles will be dumped on Ukraine
column3: affecting its people.We must keep our focus on that
column4: which is what we have been doing. I will come to the other issue
column5: but the manner in which the Russian Federation has done this contrasts completely with what the EU has done
column6: which has been to be entirely open about how we issue sanctions
column7: namely
column8: people passing laws-----

column1: #VeronaMurphy	unknown-#VeronaMurphy-party	unknown-#VeronaMurphy-dob	unknown-#VeronaMurphy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	304	We must move on to the question on the Horn of Africa. That is the question the Deputy wants answered.

#ThomasByrne	unknown-#ThomasByrne-party	unknown-#ThomasByrne-dob	unknown-#ThomasByrne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	305	The actions of the Russian Federation have entailed a lot of criticism for the Irish Government from the Opposition
column2: which I find extraordinary. Several Deputies rightly raised the situation in the Horn of Africa. This is extremely serious. The Horn of Africa is experiencing its most severe drought in more than 40 years
column3: which has led to high levels of acute food insecurity and malnutrition. As Deputies have said
column4: 36 million people are affected. The number has increased from approximately 19 million that were affected in July. The numbers are staggering and shocking. It is right that Deputies have raised this. It is also right that the Government is providing support and is actively involved in the region. By the end of this year
column5: Ireland will have provided more than €100 million to our humanitarian and development partners in the region. We remain fully committed in that regard. We are providing lifesaving humanitarian aid and longer term development programmes to address food insecurity. Communities in the region are also supported through multilateral humanitarian action
column6: including the UN's Central Emergency Response Fund. Ireland has already given €11.5 million to this fund.

column1: #VeronaMurphy	unknown-#VeronaMurphy-party	unknown-#VeronaMurphy-dob	unknown-#VeronaMurphy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	306	That is all right.

#ThomasByrne	unknown-#ThomasByrne-party	unknown-#ThomasByrne-dob	unknown-#ThomasByrne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	307	It is important to put all of this on the record. It is so important.

#VeronaMurphy	unknown-#VeronaMurphy-party	unknown-#VeronaMurphy-dob	unknown-#VeronaMurphy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	308	It is
column2: but the Minister of State will have to do it within the time allowed.

column1: #ThomasByrne	unknown-#ThomasByrne-party	unknown-#ThomasByrne-dob	unknown-#ThomasByrne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	309	The EU itself will have contributed more than €5 billion in humanitarian and development assistance for global food security.

#VeronaMurphy	unknown-#VeronaMurphy-party	unknown-#VeronaMurphy-dob	unknown-#VeronaMurphy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	310	We may have time for a second round.

#ThomasByrne	unknown-#ThomasByrne-party	unknown-#ThomasByrne-dob	unknown-#ThomasByrne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	311	I welcome as well the ceasefire in Ethiopia between the government there and the Tigrayan leaders in recent days. That is very important and I hope it can be implemented in full and work to the advantage of the people.

#MattieMcGrath	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-party	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-dob	unknown-#MattieMcGrath-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	312	The Minister of State might answer my question today
column2: although he did not on the previous occasion I asked him in the House
column3: about the number of warships that recently docked in the harbour of Cork. Was that with the imprimatur of the Government? The ships were from Canada and Great Britain
column4: among other places. Why are they there and why are they being minded by a large number of gardaí? When anybody approaches them peacefully
column5: not to damage a warship
column6: by walking up to it and asking questions
column7: armed and unarmed gardaí arrive. The other question I would like the Minister of State to respond to is on whose authority the Taoiseach decided we are not a neutral country anymore. He stated a number of times that our neutrality is outdated and we can see that by his actions. On whose authority is he acting? We had no debate on that in this House. We had no plebiscite or referendum on the matter. As a buachaill óg
column8: I always understood that our neutrality was sacrosanct. I was in the same party as the Minister of State. Has this all changed with the Taoiseach
column9: Deputy Micheál Martin
column10: in his quest to become a European Commissioner or whatever else in Europe? On whose authority can he sign up to funds for various causes
column11: be it for uniforms
column12: hats or training in minesweeping? We have not had a debate on the issue. The Taoiseach has not been authorised to do anything in that regard by this Parliament
column13: certainly as far as I am aware. I am on the Business Committee and no debates have been put forward in that regard either. I would like a response to those questions. On whose authority is the Taoiseach acting? He has delayed the handover now for two more days. We must sit on 17 December
column14: despite what staff and everybody else might have to put up with almost in Christmas week
column15: so that he can attend another global summit. He is intending to go out in a blaze of glory as a globalist.

column1: #ThomasByrne	unknown-#ThomasByrne-party	unknown-#ThomasByrne-dob	unknown-#ThomasByrne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	313	I will not respond to the last point. Warships visiting ports is not a matter for the European Council
column2: so I have no information on that. I suggest that the Deputy ask a parliamentary question of the relevant Department or inquiries could be made to the Port of Cork or Cork City Council. I suppose they would have the answer. I do not have the answer
column3: as I am here to discuss the European Council
column4: and it was not raised at the European Council. Regarding neutrality
column5: the Taoiseach has made it very clear our neutrality is characterised by non-membership of military alliances. He has also said there are no plans to join any military alliance. When one country gets effectively beaten up
column6: with many of its citizens killed by another country
column7: there are very basic principles of international law that have been broken. Those basic principles come from the United Nations system
column8: an international system
column9: which the Deputy knows a previous Minister for Foreign Affairs and member of Fianna Fáil
column10: Frank Aiken
column11: played a massive role in putting together over many years. That is the system we uphold
column12: one we must uphold if we want to be a democratic state bound by the rule of law and if we want to insist that others maintain those principles. My party - Deputy Mattie McGrath's former party - has a very proud tradition in the United Nations system. The UN General Assembly
column13: on many occasions
column14: has condemned Russia's actions because they breach the basic principles of the United Nations to which we have all signed up. It is a very simple proposition for us on this side of the House. There is no issue with it whatsoever. There is no suggestion we are joining NATO
column15: that we are taking part in any common defence
column16: or that we are providing weapons to Ukraine. What we have done in the temporary protection directive is contribute to non-lethal military equipment. Austria
column17: which is also a neutral country
column18: has done the same. We have been proud to do that. The equipment is very important and has been very gratefully received by the Ukrainians.

column1: #RichardODonoghue	unknown-#RichardODonoghue-party	unknown-#RichardODonoghue-dob	unknown-#RichardODonoghue-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	314	Why is the Government so slow to respond to the European laws that are made to help the SMEs and people of Ireland? I refer to the toolbox we were given. I will give just one example. When the fuel crisis came
column2: we asked the Government to help the SMEs
column3: road hauliers and others involved in transport around the country. It introduced a fund that would only benefit those with a road haulage licence
column4: which took out 65% of the trucks and vans in this country. The Government only supplemented one side of the equation. It did not provide a supplement for everybody. Prior to the energy crisis in this country
column5: Newcastlewest had four butchers and now it has only one because of the costs. I go from town to town and village to village where we have SMEs that are relying on energy and the Government has not reacted because it does not seem to understand the consequences of all these small businesses closing down. We can see from our electricity bills that 64% of electricity comes from renewables and that we are being charged a high rate for gas. Why can the Government not react fast enough? It brought the VAT down to 9%. It gave people €600
column6: inclusive of VAT
column7: which brings it down to €550. The taxation system in this country is killing the SMEs because of the energy cost. I want to save lives
column8: families
column9: businesses
column10: and communities. Why is the Government so slow to react and help people even when Council Regulation (EU) 2022/1854 was introduced on 8 October? There will no businesses left in rural areas. It will only be the multinationals that can sustain the cost that will be able to stay open and the SMEs will close.

column1: #ThomasByrne	unknown-#ThomasByrne-party	unknown-#ThomasByrne-dob	unknown-#ThomasByrne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	315	Deputy O'Donoghue is on record as opposing the budget. His constituents this week are massively benefiting from Government supports that come from taxation to help them with their fuel bills. Every one of his constituents on the fuel allowance this week is getting an unprecedented lump sum to help them with the difficult challenges they face. The Deputy opposed it all and he keeps giving out about it.

#RichardODonoghue	unknown-#RichardODonoghue-party	unknown-#RichardODonoghue-dob	unknown-#RichardODonoghue-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	316	What about the costs for SMEs?

#ThomasByrne	unknown-#ThomasByrne-party	unknown-#ThomasByrne-dob	unknown-#ThomasByrne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	317	They are getting €600 in three lump sums to help with their bills. The Government has been working very hard and is about to introduce significant measures for the SME sector. We have done a large amount at European level. We have gone to the European Union and worked together with all the other governments and we have made these decisions together. We have taken action to attract new gas supplies into the European market
column2: including for ourselves. European Union countries have stored 90% of their requirements. Many Deputies
column3: including Deputy Murnane O'Connor
column4: to be fair to her
column5: welcomed the regulation on an emergency intervention to address high energy prices. That is about demand reduction
column6: but there is also a cap on energy companies making excessive profits from renewables and other sources as well as making a solidarity contribution from fossil fuel profits. One Deputy asked about the delay
column7: but if he had read the regulation
column8: we are required to comply with it from 1 December. There is extensive work involved in doing that. I accept the price of energy is a key consideration for us
column9: but the businesses in Deputy O'Donoghue's constituency
column10: in my constituency and throughout the country also need security of supply. We must make sure we can give them the supply. There are two sides to the equation: getting the price down and making sure we have the supply. The Government has been entirely focused on that. By any measure
column11: we have achieved substantial results in the face of the crisis and we will continue to work on the situation as well.

column1: #ThomasPringle	unknown-#ThomasPringle-party	unknown-#ThomasPringle-dob	unknown-#ThomasPringle-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	318	I was not aware there was a question and answer session. I have two questions about the military support for Ukraine and the training effort that will take place in Europe. What will Ireland's role be in that regard and in terms of participation in the event?On the cost of gas and electricity
column2: the document says the Council meeting in December will address this again. Are we going to see concrete proposals to address the issue after December? When will the proposals come forward?

column1: #ThomasByrne	unknown-#ThomasByrne-party	unknown-#ThomasByrne-dob	unknown-#ThomasByrne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-11-16 00:00:00	Ábhair Shaincheisteanna Tráthúla - Topical Issue Matters	319	The issue of military assistance and de-mining is at an early stage. The Minister for Defence
column2: Deputy Coveney
column3: would be in a better position to discuss that. We welcome the agreement reached to established an EU military assistance mission in support of Ukraine. Ireland is engaging with Ukraine at present to assess how best to respond to its specific request for support in the area of de-mining where
column4: as the Taoiseach noted last week we have some expertise. To be fair
column5: the Ukrainians have severe needs and the whole area of mines is the classic civilian problem both during wartime and thereafter
column6: where ordinary people are put at risk because of the mines that have been planted. We have some expertise and that help could be provided through the EU military assistance mission but there is work to be done on that. The Minister for Defence and the Taoiseach undoubtedly will be able to provide the Dáil with further information. As I stated in respect of energy
column7: a lot has been achieved. I have already listed out what has been achieved to Deputy O'Donoghue and more work is ongoing. The Deputy is correct that the Heads of Government and State will return to this issue in December. It is important work and takes time. The fact that there can be disagreements or complexities around this issue is a feature rather than a flaw of the European system. We are working together to protect all of our national interests
column8: all of which are important
column9: but we also realise the importance of working together as member states of the European Union
column10: contrary to what Deputy Mattie McGrath alleges
column11: at all European debates
column12: about there being some kind of conspiracy. We should try to keep conspiracy theories out of the Dáil and this whole thing about globalism is a conspiracy theory. There is no conspiracy. The governments try to work together for their peoples in the knowledge that by doing so
column13: we get better results for the European people as a whole. We in Ireland have a specific situation in respect of gas because our gas supply is not connected to the continental European market
column14: and we must protect that. To be fair to the other member states
column15: they recognise that. When you start looking around the table
column16: however
column17: you see that each country or region has its own specificities that must be addressed as well. We are not unique in that regard.

Tá Éire go mór ar son an chaidrimh idir an tAontas Eorpach agus ASEAN. Is clochmhíle shuntasach í an chomhpháirtíocht 45 bliain idir AE agus ASEAN.
